bug.author: rasbt
bug.summary: [JOSS] how to set up the mlpack Python bindings
bug.description:
I followed the installation instructions and everything went super smoothly thus far! :) I can use the binaries from within the bin folder, and also the tests all pass: ~/mlpack-3.0.1/build$ bin/mlpack_test Running 1351 test cases...
... warning: solve(): system appears singular (rcond: 1.31214e-18); attempting approximate solution
warning: solve(): system appears singular (rcond: 1.31214e-18); attempting approximate solution
*** No errors detected I am wondering now what step would be required to enable the Python bindings? Would I just need to add ~/mlpack-3.0.1/src/mlpack/bindings/python/mlpack to my Python PATH? It would be nice if that could be briefly explained in the documentation (maybe in the "building from source" docs).

comments.comment:
Honestly I'd say make install is the easiest way to do it, like the build directions suggest. If you really want to do it manually in the build directory it's hard enough that I wanted to avoid adding it to the documentation... from the build directory: <denchmark-code>export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=lib/ export PYTHONPATH=src/mlpack/bindings/python/ </denchmark-code>
If you make install it will put it in /usr/local/lib/pythonX.Y/site-packages/ which should automatically be in the PYTHONPATH. As I write this though, I do think you are right, it would be useful to add a section to the build documentation mentioning how to work with the Python bindings without installing. I'll do that when I have a chance.

If you make install it will put it in /usr/local/lib/pythonX.Y/site-packages/ which should automatically be in the PYTHONPATH.
Hm, I used that, but for some reason, it didn't add anything to the site-packages directory (checked both the python 2.7 and 3.5 dirs), which is why I assumed a manual step might be necessary (I used sudo make install) >>> import mlpack Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> ImportError: No module named mlpack
As I write this though, I do think you are right, it would be useful to add a section to the build documentation mentioning how to work with the Python bindings without installing. I'll do that when I have a chance.
Thanks, that would be nice.

That's strange. Mind posting the output of make install (it will be long...)? The Python bindings are pretty fiddly and I've found that different systems behave pretty differently. (The Python bindings are also available via pip for manylinux platforms but where's the fun in that?? :))

Sure np! I think the problem could be that the bindings are installed in /usr/local/include/mlpack -- not sure if that's intended? ~/mlpack-3.0.1/build$ sudo make install [ 0%] Updating arma_config.hpp (if Does 'make python' work?

For the whole installation procedure, I used a fresh Ubuntu install (16.04 LTS) and followed the docs step by step, including <denchmark-code>$ sudo apt-get install libboost-math-dev libboost-program-options-dev libboost-test-dev libboost-serialization-dev libarmadillo-dev binutils-dev python-pandas python-numpy cython python-setuptools </denchmark-code>
Usually, I use the Miniconda Python distribution, however, for this review, I thought it would be better to follow the installation step by step without any dependencies installed that are not listed. Do you think the Cmake step doesn't work with the system's Python, and is there any good way to check that?

Right, in this case, it looks like CMake didn't find everything right for the Python bindings. I wonder if the Cython version is too old or something. Can you run cmake ../ in the build directory and print the output? It should show some information about the Python bindings and whether the dependencies could be detected.

Actually, I bet the Cython version is too old: <denchmark-link:https://packages.ubuntu.com/xenial/cython>https://packages.ubuntu.com/xenial/cython</denchmark-link>
The Cython version needs to be 0.24 or newer, so you could try on Ubuntu 17.10, but unfortunately 16.04 is pretty old at this point (or nobody has backported a newer version yet).

You are right!
CMake Warning at CMake/FindPythonModule.cmake:44 (message): Unsuitable version of Python module Cython (0.24 or greater required).
Will try a newer Ubuntu version then

PS: apt-get install pkg-config could be added to the dependency list, i.e., in the lines <denchmark-code># apt-get install libboost-math-dev libboost-program-options-dev libboost-test-dev libboost-serialization-dev libarmadillo-dev binutils-dev python-pandas python-numpy cython python-setuptools </denchmark-code>
since it doesn't come with Ubuntu by default.

If it's installed to /usr/local/, on some systems (including Ubuntu) this is not in the default linker search path. So you'll need to export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/lib/ since that's where libmlpack.so.3 is. pkg-config isn't a requirement for building, though, it's optional---so if it's not there, no problem. (You just can't use pkg-config later to link against mlpack, for instance.)

(more details in the README at the end of section 4: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/mlpack/mlpack#4-building-mlpack-from-source>https://github.com/mlpack/mlpack#4-building-mlpack-from-source</denchmark-link> )
